A. Environmental influence inheritance – This refers to traits being influenced by the environment beyond the DNA sequence.

C. Epigenetic inheritance – This involves changes in gene expression due to environmental factors, so not directly about inheritance per se.

D. Genetic inheritance – This is Mendelian-like, involving the transmission of alleles via parents passing them on to offspring.

E. Bilateral inheritance – This is when two copies of an allele are inherited from one parent, typically from the father, though sometimes from the mother too.

F. Pollen inheritance – This would involve pollen grains carrying certain alleles, which could affect plant development but doesn't explain phenotypic variation among individuals unless multiple parents contribute.

G. Mendelian dominant-recessive – Similar to D but specifies dominance and recessive traits.

H. Cytoplasmic (maternal) inheritance – This involves maternal effects, meaning the maternal genotype affects the offspring's phenotype. However, cytoplasmic effects are more complex and less commonly observed than epigenetics or Mendelian inheritance.

I. Paternal inheritance – This is similar to H but specifically paternal effects, where the father's genotype influences the child's phenotype.

J. Multifactorial inheritance – This refers to situations where multiple factors (like genes, environment, etc.) interact to determine the phenotype.
